parts.instructions: You are going to read an article about the future of work. For questions 1-6, choose the answer (A, B, C or D) which you think fits best according to the text.

passage.title: The Digital Nomad Revolution
passage.content:
Maria Gonzalez closed her laptop and looked out at the Mediterranean coastline from her temporary office in a Barcelona caf√©. As a software developer for a tech company based in New York, she was part of a growing movement of digital nomads who had redefined what it means to go to work.

'Five years ago, my boss would never have allowed me to work from another continent,' Maria reflected during a video call with her colleague James in Seattle. 'Now, as long as I deliver quality work on time, the company doesn't care if I'm in Barcelona, Bangkok, or Boston.'

The digital nomad lifestyle had emerged from advances in cloud computing, collaboration software, and high-speed internet connectivity. What began as an experiment during the pandemic had evolved into a permanent shift in how many knowledge workers approached their careers.

However, this new freedom came with unexpected challenges. Maria had discovered that working across multiple time zones required exceptional time management skills. 'I sometimes find myself on calls at 2 AM local time to accommodate team meetings,' she noted. 'The flexibility is amazing, but it demands more discipline than traditional office work.'

Tax implications represented another complexity that many digital nomads hadn't anticipated. Working from different countries for extended periods could trigger tax obligations in multiple jurisdictions. 'I now work with an international tax advisor,' Maria explained. 'The cost is worth it, but it's something I never had to consider when I worked from a single location.'

The social aspects of nomadic work also required adaptation. While Maria enjoyed the cultural experiences and new environments, she sometimes missed the spontaneous conversations and collaborative energy of a shared office space. 'Video calls are efficient, but they can't completely replace face-to-face interaction,' she observed.

Despite these challenges, Maria remained committed to the nomadic lifestyle. She had visited twelve countries in the past two years while maintaining her career trajectory and even receiving a promotion. 'The traditional model of being tied to one location for your entire career is becoming obsolete,' she concluded. 'Technology has given us the freedom to design our lives around our work, rather than the other way around.'

options: A) They provide better work-life balance.

parts.instructions: You are going to read an article about artificial intelligence in the workplace. Six paragraphs have been removed from the article. Choose from the paragraphs A-G the one which fits each gap (7-12). There is one extra paragraph which you do not need to use.

passage.title: AI and the Future of Human Work
passage.content:
Artificial intelligence is transforming workplaces across industries, creating both opportunities and challenges for human workers. Understanding how to adapt to these changes will be crucial for career success in the coming decades.

[7]

Rather than replacing human workers entirely, AI is more often augmenting human capabilities. In healthcare, AI systems help doctors analyze medical images more accurately, while in finance, algorithms assist analysts in identifying market trends.

[8]

The key to thriving alongside AI lies in developing uniquely human skills that machines cannot easily replicate. Creativity, emotional intelligence, complex problem-solving, and ethical reasoning remain distinctly human domains.

[9]

However, this transition requires significant investment in education and training programs. Workers whose jobs are being automated need opportunities to develop new skills and transition to emerging roles.

[10]

The pace of AI development means that continuous learning has become essential for all workers, not just those in technology fields. Professionals must stay informed about how AI might impact their specific industry and role.

[11]

Organizations that successfully integrate AI while supporting their human workforce often see the greatest benefits. These companies invest in training programs and create new roles that leverage both human and artificial intelligence.

[12]

As AI continues to evolve, the most successful workers will be those who view it as a powerful tool to enhance their capabilities rather than a threat to their livelihood.

paragraphs.text: Many economists predict that AI will create more jobs than it eliminates, though these new positions will require different skills than traditional roles.
This collaboration between humans and machines often produces better results than either could achieve independently.
Companies that ignore the human element of AI integration often struggle with employee resistance and poor implementation outcomes.
These skills become more valuable as AI handles routine and predictable tasks, freeing humans to focus on higher-level thinking and relationship building.
Government policies and corporate responsibility will play crucial roles in ensuring that the benefits of AI are shared broadly across society.
This means developing learning mindsets and being willing to adapt career paths as new technologies emerge.
The most effective approach often involves retraining existing employees rather than replacing them entirely.

parts.instructions: You are going to read about four people working in environmental sustainability. For questions 13-22, choose from the people (A-D). The people may be chosen more than once.

people.name: Dr. Ana Rivera - Climate Researcher
people.text: I study the long-term effects of climate change on coastal ecosystems using advanced computer modeling and field research. My work involves collecting data from remote locations, often in challenging weather conditions. The research requires collaboration with international teams and extensive travel to research stations in polar regions. I frequently present findings to policymakers and environmental organizations to inform climate action strategies. The urgency of climate issues means our research timelines are often compressed, creating pressure to produce results quickly while maintaining scientific rigor. Despite the serious nature of our findings, I remain optimistic that human ingenuity and cooperation can address these environmental challenges.

people.name: Carlos Mendez - Renewable Energy Engineer
people.text: I design and implement solar and wind energy systems for both residential and commercial clients. Each project requires careful analysis of local weather patterns, energy needs, and site conditions. The technology is advancing rapidly, with new developments in battery storage and energy efficiency emerging constantly. I work closely with architects, city planners, and electrical contractors to integrate renewable systems into existing infrastructure. Financial incentives and government policies significantly impact project feasibility, so I stay informed about policy changes. The most satisfying aspect of my work is seeing families and businesses reduce their carbon footprint while saving money on energy costs.

people.name: Isabella Santos - Sustainable Agriculture Specialist
people.text: I help farmers transition to organic and sustainable farming practices that protect soil health and reduce environmental impact. This involves developing crop rotation plans, implementing natural pest control methods, and training farmers in sustainable techniques. The transition period can be financially challenging for farmers, as organic certification takes time and yields may initially decrease. I work with agricultural cooperatives and government agencies to provide financial support and technical assistance during this transition. Consumer education is also crucial - people need to understand the connection between farming practices and environmental health. Seeing degraded farmland restored to productivity through sustainable methods is incredibly rewarding.

people.name: Miguel Torres - Environmental Policy Analyst
people.text: I research and develop environmental policies for government agencies and non-profit organizations. My work involves analyzing the potential impacts of proposed legislation on both environmental protection and economic development. I regularly attend public hearings and community meetings to gather input from various stakeholders, including businesses, environmental groups, and local residents. Balancing competing interests is often challenging, but effective environmental policy must consider economic realities alongside ecological concerns. I collaborate with lawyers, scientists, and economists to ensure policies are both scientifically sound and legally feasible. The legislative process can be slow and frustrating, but creating lasting environmental protections makes the effort worthwhile.
